item.title: 365 – NYE
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: NYE How do we approach an end that is, in fact, not? * We’ll glitz around tonight champagned and fluted, reveling in the last gasps of what the year was and was not. We’ll reminisce, bloviate, apologize and obfuscate. There’ll … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
NYE

How do we approach an end
that is, in fact, not?

*

We’ll glitz around tonight
champagned and fluted, reveling

in the last gasps of what the year was
and was not. We’ll reminisce,

bloviate, apologize and
obfuscate. There’ll be fondue

and crudité. We’ll play
pin the tail

on the donkey, the ass’s head
gotten by some quick devilry.

We’ll cry Wassail! and bless the trees
out in the frozen yard.

We’ll drink too much
and dress in drag

flying what secret flags
we hide away.

It will all be games.
Until

at a certain moment,
someone will shout for quiet

and we’ll all gather round
to watch

a lighted ball descend
in Times Square.

We’ll count down
en masse, on mute

the ending
and beginning

of it all, looking
for all the world

as if we never saw it
coming.

How sad and lovely.
How very human.

item.title: 364 – Dirty Jokes & Ducks
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Dirty Jokes & Ducks Bed down the year, you frozen oaks. I can see right through your spiral skirts, branches benching against the sky peeling blue, two-tone, skimming ice like glass in the mudflats. The left-over mallards are bastards, laughing at obscene … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Dirty Jokes & Ducks

Bed down the year, you
frozen oaks. I can see right through
your spiral skirts, branches benching
against the sky peeling blue,
two-tone, skimming ice
like glass in the mudflats.

The left-over mallards are bastards,
laughing at obscene duck jokes.
My knees get ahead of me,
saying Don’t forget the body
is a standing casket
in their creaky tongue.

I call bullshit out loud
to a yellow dog running ragged
circles around a reddened woman.
They both stop, stilled
by my voice and the small truth
held in it,

though the dog never quits
his tail, but cocks a furrowed brow
my way. I take his meaning.
On the walk home, I compose
my own dirty jokes to tell
my wife and friends.

We’ll laugh this old year out
and surprise the New
with the dark well of our bellies
and the red-hot flash
of our rolling tongues,
streaked with joy.

item.title: 363 – Path
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Path Words like Christ are broken reeds wind blows upon whistling wind against me. Where is my friend I hold in grief? Who shores me up in joy? I’m about done turned out at the end of this long year … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Path

Words like Christ are broken
reeds wind blows upon whistling
wind against me. Where is my friend
I hold in grief? Who shores me up
in joy? I’m about done turned out
at the end of this long year
needing more than myths and men
of standing. Need none of them.
Need  God to get down
in my shoes, shove his bloodied feet
in, tread the miles. Words are little
help along this path; walk
a ways and see what comes
of steady movement, faith
in one unsteady foot
in front of the other.

item.title: 362 – Blessing (Honeycomb)
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Blessing (Honeycomb) I am weary of these poems carved of bitterness and loss, spun from finely turned doubts. I long for bees and heron’s blue shadow overhead, for the fox grinning his tail into his hole just ahead of the … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Blessing (Honeycomb)

I am weary
of these poems
carved of bitterness
and loss, spun
from finely turned
doubts.

I long for bees
and heron’s blue
shadow overhead,

for the fox grinning
his tail into his hole
just ahead of the hound,
who is happy
to be hunting, alive
in his body.

Where is the raucous yellow?
Where the whale’s song sounding
so like the seas of the heart?

The poems I crave
bloom like morels, hidden
in the feet of things,
covered in rain and rot,
not apart from, but one with.

Honeycomb sweetens
in the presence
of the sting.

item.title: 361 – Ninevah
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Nineveh Twisted root. Blemished dove. Spotted ram of Jacob. I may pluck out my right eye. Even now the right hands bears aloft the sword to lop away the withered left. Yet I may still cross the Jordan, circle seven … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Nineveh

Twisted root.
Blemished dove.
Spotted ram of Jacob. I
may pluck out my right eye.
Even now the right hands bears
aloft the sword to lop away
the withered left.

Yet I may still cross the Jordan,
circle seven times the walls
of my life, waiting on the ram’s horn.
I might yet find my way to Nineveh,
may feel the burning coal against my lips.

I may yet shake the dust.

item.title: 360 – Apology
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Apology What I want is to say is I am sorry. I know the words of apology in two languages. It is impossible. I had my chance, as we all do, to right the words behind my teeth and send … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Apology

What I want is to say is
I am sorry.

I know the words
of apology in two languages.

It is impossible.

I had my chance,
as we all do,

to right the words behind my teeth
and send them out as envoys.

I did not take my chance.

I washed my hands
in a tiled room

and took my leave, smiling
with closed lips.

I left them to rot
in my mouth,

dissolving
on my reluctant tongue

seeping back into my body.

item.title: 359 – Desert (Christmas)
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Desert (Christmas) In the desert your voice alone touches the rocks and itself in passing. Your shadow’s thin body caught up in the spines of the saguaro. What prayers the ancient cisterns hold is water that slakes but only a … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Desert (Christmas)

In the desert
your voice alone
touches the rocks
and itself in passing.

Your shadow’s thin
body caught up
in the spines
of the saguaro.

What prayers
the ancient cisterns hold
is water that slakes
but only a little while.

As if God came not
into the world, as if
God is not shadow
and voice, not water

in the desert.

item.title: 358 – Ugly Christmas (Eve) Poem
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Ugly Christmas (Eve) Poem All I want for Christmas is a little cherry Benadryl crushed up in some apple juice for the cranky kid in 12E kicking the back of my seat all the way to Phoenix. Merry Christmas to … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Ugly Christmas (Eve) Poem

All I want for Christmas
is a little cherry Benadryl
crushed up in some apple juice
for the cranky kid in 12E
kicking the back of my seat
all the way to Phoenix.
Merry Christmas to all
and to all a good night.

item.title: 357 – Rosary
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Rosary At thirty-one my grandmother taught me to pray with a complimentary plastic rosary left by the Sisters of Providence. This bright white Christ hung, so thin, from her thick arthritic hands, furred black by blood thinners. Our Father who art  in heaven?  I … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Rosary

At thirty-one my grandmother taught me to pray
with a complimentary plastic rosary
left by the Sisters of Providence.

This bright white Christ hung, so thin,
from her thick arthritic hands, furred black
by blood thinners.

Our Father
who art 
in heaven? 

I asked it as a question;
she corrected me, gently
starting over again.

We did the decades,
hailing Mary, full of grace,
until she tired and fell

asleep. I kissed her cheek
and gently smuggled Jesus
into my hip pocket.

Strung from the rearview he listened
as I mangled the ordered prayers
all the way home. I trust he got the gist.

item.title: 356 – Advent (viii)
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Advent (viii) hammered gold leaf around the melting chocolate coin in the woven toe hung with such care -lessness the cat bats it back and forth the tree is piney dead duff and dying dried to tinder flame gone up … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Advent (viii)

hammered gold leaf
around the melting
chocolate coin
in the woven toe
hung with such care
-lessness the cat bats
it back and forth
the tree is piney dead
duff and dying dried
to tinder flame gone
up and out awake
the sleeping babes
awaiting father
Christmas coming?
empty bottles spin
leave the wilting cactus
without blooms
the cartoned waste
and unstrung bows
the smiling cards
of faces known
long ago and sent
by rote what joy
is in the hurried
holiday? a font
of peace and love
and joy on earth
goodwill to men
so seeming feint.
though star of stars
gleams bright
its said hung eastern
and drawing near
if sages and stories
hold truth as dear
as hope. in this
dark night
the soul, mine
own, awaits
one promised
crying as we all
have cried, groaning
through the flock
and brash of this
the longest season,
aching for the morn
to break, the light
to fall and rise and shine.
